documents.title: 2026 Yearly Plan - Consumer Mega-Alliance (Final) - Q1
documents.content:
ÔªøFinal YP





üí° Meeting Notes [To be filled after the Review Meeting by the YP Document Owner and sent out via email to attendees. This section does not impact the maximum number of pages]

Review Meeting Date: Oct 16, 2025

Attendees: Ed Boyes Assaf Ronen Dominik Richter Holger Hammel,Cho HwangAnnie MeininghausDina MehrezThomas GrieselFabien SimonMarlene RosnerBrian LeungAdriana VillarEvan WeintraubJama Musse





Key Takeaways, Decisions, and Next Steps:

1. Clarify how menu expansion plans, personalization roll outs  and app features come together: 

   * Elysium (new store and homepage in the app) roll out is fast followed by new app feature which benefits users  irrespective of menu ranking roll out (most notably merchandising widgets for marketing,  recommendation widgets,bringing search to apps, populating ‚Äúmost popular, ‚Äútrending‚Äù widgets - details)

   * Menu ranking roll out: At the same time there is a roll out plan for menu ranking models which prioritizes P500 readiness in Q4/Q1 as well as Penguin for Factor US. Food Systems is trying to expedite Penguin for INTL if possible, prioritized after p500. Fall back is to launch Penguin Harp personalization to INTL markets expanding in Q1.  Other RTE markets in H2.

2. Share prioritization framework  for Project 5M. The prioritization is heavily influenced by successful companies and features observed (direct or indirect competitors) as well as through an internal workshop. This revealed a consistent and significant behavioral gap: Users enthusiastically save recipes (often from social media) but rarely act on them. This indicates a high desire for inspiration but a significant friction point in execution. This led to the prioritization of the recipe bridge in Q4/Q1. If requested we can  walk through the detailed methodology.

3. Decouple forecasting from personalization models. Food Systems to define technical interfaces enabling independent iteration. Once validated, assess org impact in Q1‚ÄìQ2.

4. Reconcile marketing RAF plan with tech YP.  We have addressed the  gap between Marketing and Consumer growth targets. Share squad will focus on strengthening the Refer-a-Friend (RAF) program while building new in-product sharing loops to drive organic growth. prioritizing foundational fixes ‚Äî improving data visibility, customer experience, and operational agility ‚Äî to make the RAF program self-sufficient and easier to optimize without tech dependencies. 

5. Variable pricing is an urgently requested feature by markets. We added it  to the Market Innovation squad backlog H2. Will define long-term ownership before initiation as we are currently moving pricing ownership to growth MA. 





Changes requested to the Yearly Plan during Draft Reviews. Please update before submission for final YP approval:  

* Should we invest into an AOV-focused squad? Yes we will self fund a new AOV driven squad in Q2 with a dedicated KPI. Focus in Q1  is first to roll out the new personalized core journey including widgets and then layer in more upselling components. 

* Loyalty strategy across markets: We decided to reserve a small team to  maintain and improve the existing  program while implementing  the new vendor based loyalty program to launch first in  the US . See Loyalty Strategy SMT Shareout.

* Double check if all Factor requirements are in the plan: All documents were collected and integrated into the Market Innovation backlog. To be signed off by Ed Boyes





	I. Organizational Overview

Mission and Focus areas

The Consumer Mega Alliance vision is to create the best digital product exper



-Q2. Focus is first to roll out the personalized core journey. Consider establishing a dedicated squad to drive AOV growth by separating merchandising ownership from shopping guidance, incorporating programs.

	Annie Meininghaus

	Personalization Model Rollout (Penguin & Harp)

	Prioritize P500 readiness in Q4/Q1 as well as Penguin for Factor US. Expand personalization to INTL markets (100‚Äì150 meals)  HF-UK, HF-CA, CP-CA (TBD), HF-ANZ, HF-BNL, HF-DKSE, HF-DEAT will follow Q1 / Q2. Other RTE markets in H2. Details in Ops Alliance YP.

	Annie Meininghaus

	Decouple Forecasting from Personalization Models

	Food Systems to define technical interfaces enabling independent iteration. Once validated, assess org impact in Q1‚ÄìQ2. See Forecasting Domain Boundaries.

	Holger Hammel

	Factor Tech Requests Review

	Jama and Annie aligned with Adam Park to merge the Factor backlog with the Market Innovation squad list. Requests are now integrated and can be selected during quarterly planning.

	Jama Musse

	Variable Pricing

	Added to the Market Innovation squad backlog. Deferred until Q3. Will define long-term ownership before initiation.

	Jama Musse

	Factor Programs Transition Plan

	Pause Programs on Factor funnel for peak since results are negative. Alison Ryanwill partner with Commercial and New Programs hire in NA to design a better ‚ÄúActive Experience‚Äù and 3rd-party partnerships. Aligned timeline is Q2.

	Jama Musse

	Project 5M Prioritization (App Engagement)

	Lisa Trueblood preparing a one-pager summarizing prioritization framework and decisions for follow-up discussion.

	Evan Weintraub

	Loyalty Strategy Across Markets

	Decided to reserve 20% of engineering IC capacity to maintain and improve the legacy program while evolving the new loyalty framework. See Loyalty Strategy SMT Shareout.

	Evan Weintraub

	Referral (RAF) Program Alignment

	Address gap between Marketing and Consumer growth targets. Share‚Äù squad will focus on strengthening the Refer-a-Friend (RAF) program while building new in-product sharing loops to drive organic growth. prioritizing foundational fixes ‚Äî improving data visibility, customer experience, and operational agility ‚Äî to make the RAF program self-sufficient and easier to optimize without tech dependencies. Updated FAQ 11 

	Evan Weintraub

	



[a]@leo.lee@hellofresh.ca @fernando.desouza@hellofresh.com @jama.musse@hellofresh.ca FYI

documents.title: Notes - AI Bytes Assemble
documents.content:
ÔªøSyncs

Resources

* AI-Native Product Development Handbook

* AI-First vs. AI-Augmented: Why Focus Winsx

Backlog

* Shipyard Concept Experiment PM + Eng + Design ‚Üí take an idea through to the outcome (overlaps with Ebrahim‚Äôs AI lab concept)

Dec 18, 2025

* Aligning on scope across boundaries

   * Design to Code

   * RN

   * Scaling adoption of AI-first PDLC AI-Native Product Development Handbook

Dec 15, 2025

Agenda

* [Mario] Establishing a Golden Path for an AI-Native Product Development Lifecycle (PDLC) - Foundation for Q1 Planning

* [AG] AI-First vs. AI-Augmented: Why Focus Wins

* [ALL] How might we merge our view points to see eye to eye? What‚Äôs next?

Decision Doc: Q1'2026 Planning Alignment Foundations + Consumer Foundations

* [MK] I feel we are aligned on

* Focus on the design-to-code part of the PDLC

* Focus on well-defined use cases (ReactNative migration, anything else directly related to the meta backlog) vs. rolling out to all

That said, I need to understand the ReactNative use cases a bit better

Main question for me right now: How to assess success (quantitatively)

* Setting standards would require guidelines





Key minutes & action items (besides Gemini)

* [Sergei]RN x GenAI Session

Nov 20, 2025

Status Updates:

Adam

Nikita

Pep

Ebrahim

Lacey

* Releasing FreshChat integration in HelloDev today

* Formal launch of AI Agent Platform tomorrow

* Pricilla

Brian

Shereif









Oct 27, 2025

Agenda

* [Sherief] How to enable better QA processes for Marketing teams

* #web-marketing-campaign-issues-na-mealkits ‚Üí channel with errors reporting

* [NG + Leo] ChatGPT App PoC launched  -Draft- [PRD] HF Discovery MCP / ChatGPT App Integration POC

* [Leo] Request for clarity on pilot PDLC program and path forward

AI-Native Product Development Handbook 

* [AG+NG] Breaking down what‚Äôs needed to get to PDLC iteratively

* [AG] Feedback on /qa-test command





Minutes & action items

   * Adam Ghanem to refine Gemini minutes & action items to align with the group on next steps across key topics over the next 2 weeks









Status updates





Adam

   * Past 2 weeks: little has been done, most of the focus was solely on YP and re-org people ops

   * Small win: Created a /qa-test Claude Code command that is able to generate a test plan scenario (e.g. given a list of all the prices for specific zones, create a test report showing where are there pricing display errors)

   * Booked for 50% of AI Office Hours this week without re-announcement

   * Needed from the group: need feedback from people testing the /qa-test command - where it falls short, etc..

   * What‚Äôs in focus next? 

   * Introducing AI Bytes Office Hours to a wider audience of product managers & designers

   * Claude Code for Product Management Workshop w/ Ebrahim[a]

   * What am I interested in updates about?

   * v0 procurement & next steps for how might we shift to a prototype first culture for consumer facing experiences

   * @Ebrahim/@Pep methodology of spec-driven development core concepts intro rotation? Sup? [b][c][d][e][f]

   * Also can we be a bit more specific of the goals of the teams‚Äô you‚Äôre onboarding? 

   * I believe the focus right now should solely be on getting teams going with spec-driven development vs. whatever they‚Äôre doing themselves right now

   * What I need help with: 

   * Streamlining outbound efforts: templating our outbound efforts (e.g. daily tips, daily office hours, monthly workshop, weekly learning & development sources, weekly spotlight, etc..)

   * What I want us to focus on next:

   * Getting



n start slicing and dicing to creating effective tooling for - there are certain big rock efforts being made but there could be a bit more we could to speed up if we split it between us

[i]!! Definitely need to hear more about this!

[j]1 total reaction

Sherief Helaifi-Chadha reacted with ü´† at 2025-10-27 13:45 PM

[k]Connect with Srishti and Harneet on this

[l]OH MY THIS IS NICE! :)

[m]let's discuss in our 1:1 this week then briefly but my take on focus first would be on getting value out of it first then deciding if that value's worth keeping or moving over to an alternative product

[n]For which team? Consumer? Yarra and Abdel? (there's lots of taste profile teams haha

[o]@priscila.machado@hellofresh.com

[p]What's missing here?

[q]Out of curiosity, how often do we need to do competitive analysis?

[r]If we think this is really important I would DM people asking if they have something to share. If yes why they are not sharing it. Historically, I had way more survey answers when messaging people direct and trying to figure out why they where not answering it.

[s]Could we have access to the files @ekar@hellofresh.com ?

_Assigned to ekar@hellofresh.com_

[t]@adam.ghanem@hellofresh.com idea: could we video record these session, and later on create some snap shot videos (like Youtube shorts) and post it in the channel

_Assigned to adam.ghanem@hellofresh.com_

[u]Can we schedule a demo

1 total reaction

Where are you deploying it? 

How are you monitoring it? 

What have you set as success metrics?

[w]I can help once I get through this x-sell launch !

[x]What is the agenda?

[y]yes, can we first please have a learning outcome and expected learnings + prerequisites

1 total reaction

[aa]Let's make an AI Wizard Award - let's talk to Jake Fear

[ab]Sounds good - let's see what we could do

[ac]This would be great for the strategizer agent

_Assigned to nikita.gorshkov@hellofresh.com_

documents.title: Your Virtual Interview with HelloFresh | [TECH-CA] Staff Engineer - Frontend [TAM] - 2025/12/22 06:50 EST - Notes by Gemini
documents.content:
Ôªøüìù Notes

Dec 22, 2025

Your Virtual Interview with HelloFresh | [TECH-CA] Staff Engineer - Frontend [TAM]

Invited GoodTime Sync - [09 21] Sree Rangavazzula

Attachments Your Virtual Interview with HelloFresh | [TECH-CA] Staff Engineer - Frontend [TAM] 

Meeting records Transcript 





Summary

Nikita Gorshkov introduced the interview structure and context of the new ventures product team at HelloFresh to Sree Lakshmi Rangavazzula, who has over 13 years of front-end experience and discussed their work on unified features, stakeholder collaboration, and managing scope negotiations for timely delivery. Sree Lakshmi Rangavazzula shared their methods for communicating technical roadblocks, balancing scalability with immediate needs, addressing urgent feature requests, and coaching team members for career growth by providing ownership and exposure to stakeholder meetings. They also inquired about the HelloFresh engineering ladder, to which Nikita Gorshkov explained the reporting structure for Staff engineers and confirmed that technical improvements are prioritized with an impact statement through the normal sprint process, with up to 30% of sprint time allocated for KTLO.





Details

* Introduction and Interview Structure Nikita Gorshkov welcomed Sree Lakshmi Rangavazzula to the stakeholder interview and explained that while Sree Lakshmi Rangavazzula is interviewing for a parallel team, they will likely work together frequently due to existing predispositions between the teams (00:00:00). Nikita Gorshkov outlined the interview format, which includes introductions, context about their team, a discussion of a project Sree Lakshmi Rangavazzula is proud of, and time for Sree Lakshmi Rangavazzula's questions, with a planned duration of 45 minutes (00:01:13). Nikita Gorshkov leads the new ventures product team at HelloFresh, which focuses on launching and integrating M\&A opportunities and new brands, such as Factor and Goodshop (00:02:08).

* Sree Lakshmi Rangavazzula's Background and Experience Sree Lakshmi Rangavazzula introduced themself, noting they have over 13 years of industry experience, mainly in front-end web applications across e-commerce, medical, travel, and finance domains (00:03:19). Since joining their current global company in 2023, they have worked on unified features and applications for multiple lines of business (LOBs) and banners, which involved the challenging task of finding common, performance-effective solutions. Sree Lakshmi Rangavazzula emphasizes close collaboration with the product team when patterns of regression issues emerge, to align on business perspective and technical solutions (00:04:22).

* Stakeholder Management and Feature Development Sree Lakshmi Rangavazzula described their approach to working with stakeholders, starting with initial consultations to understand the feature's goal for scalability and reusability, referencing a homepage redesign intended to improve UX and track user activity as an example (00:05:52). They noted that stakeholders are heavily involved in the initial stages and again during functional testing for sign-off before production, with the development team taking the lead during implementation, only reaching out to stakeholders for discrepancy confirmation (00:07:18).

* Handling Timeline Challenges and Scope Negotiation Sree Lakshmi Rangavazzula provided an example where a requirement for a server-driven user interface initially estimated at five months had to be delivered within three months by leadership (00:08:37). To address this, they engaged in back-and-forth negotiati



here is it because we can build something faster in the future or is it will it have a customer impact?

 

 

00:40:03

 

Nikita Gorshkov: Both of those things together with the product manager you can create and craft a impact statement of like hey guys like if we do this this will be bring us X Y and Z why don't we invest some time right now into it. So and then it just goes into normal priorization for the

Sree Lakshmi Rangavazzula: Yeah.

Nikita Gorshkov: sprint.

Sree Lakshmi Rangavazzula: And also when we talk numbers and metrics with a proper presentation, it kind of um explains things better uh to the stakeholders. So uh do you follow the same uh similar

Nikita Gorshkov: Yep. Uh we we follow the impact uh confidence and uh efforts estimate

Sree Lakshmi Rangavazzula: approach?

Nikita Gorshkov: uh like basically framework. Uh the estimates we do on depends on what sizing but is it either FT per year or FT per weeks. Um, and that's how we size different things. Uh, confidence,

Sree Lakshmi Rangavazzula: Awesome.

Nikita Gorshkov: we have a confidence scoring system, but it, this one is a bit wishy-washy. It's a confidence in how confident are we that the business impact that we've calculated, we're actually going to be able to deliver. Um, and of course impact, we have business cases everywhere. Um, it's fairly straightforward or should be

Sree Lakshmi Rangavazzula: Uh, that's pretty much from my end as well. So,

Nikita Gorshkov: cool.

Sree Lakshmi Rangavazzula: it was great to meet you and thanks a lot for the

Nikita Gorshkov: No. Uh, look, this was uh a a pleasure from my ends.

Sree Lakshmi Rangavazzula: opportunity.

Nikita Gorshkov: Um, it was very structured. I really appreciate the in-depth answers that you actually prepared really well as well. I thought they were on point. So, um, yeah, you'll be hearing from our TA team soon.

Sree Lakshmi Rangavazzula: Yeah.

Nikita Gorshkov: I hope I'll provide the notes uh,

Sree Lakshmi Rangavazzula: Thank you. Yeah,

Nikita Gorshkov: today.

Sree Lakshmi Rangavazzula: sure. Thank you so much. Have a wonderful day ahead.

Nikita Gorshkov: You too. Likewise.

Sree Lakshmi Rangavazzula: Yeah.

Nikita Gorshkov: Happy holidays.

 

 

Transcription ended after 00:41:58





This editable transcript was computer generated and might contain errors. People can also change the text after it was created.

documents.title: Nikita / Mario - 2025/12/15 15:00 CET - Notes by Gemini
documents.content:
Ôªøüìù Notes

Dec 15, 2025

Nikita / Mario

Invited Nikita Gorshkov Mario Konschake

Attachments Nikita / Mario 

Meeting records Transcript 





Summary

Mario Konschake and Nikita Gorshkov discussed the definition and rollout of the AI-native Product Development Lifecycle (PDLC), with Mario Konschake expressing concern that product management will become a bottleneck as engineering and UX speed up without proper support for providing fast and better context. Nikita Gorshkov introduced their concept of context-driven product management, detailing a custom automated system that curates a knowledge base of entities and relationships to improve generative AI output, but raised concerns about scaling this approach due to the lack of consolidated infrastructure and the "nightmare" of locating the correct version of institutional knowledge across disparate tools. The participants compared AI models, with Nikita Gorshkov preferring Gemini over Claude for general text and deep research, and they agreed that high-value AI capabilities for product managers lie in data discovery and analysis‚Äîspecifically, using CLI tools to quickly analyze data and identify optimization opportunities.





Details

Notes Length: Standard

* Golden Path for AI-Native PDLC and Product Management Bottlenecks Mario Konschake is working with PEP to define and roll out the golden path for an AI-native Product Development Lifecycle (PDLC) (00:00:00). Mario Konschake explained that while there is a good candidate for software engineers (cloud code spec machine) and initial ideas for UX designers, product management is likely to become the bottleneck if engineering and UX speed up. The challenge lies in effectively supporting product managers in providing better and faster context to feed the development pipeline (00:01:56).

* Context-Driven Product Management and Knowledge Curation Nikita Gorshkov introduced their concept of context-driven product management, which has evolved since its initial version (00:03:19). They believe that product management is highly interconnected, requiring a lift-and-shift transition in working methods rather than peacemeal automation to gain the full benefits of AI. Nikita Gorshkov has developed a custom system using cloud code across two machines to maintain their own knowledge base of entities and relationships, which continuously learns and adds context to improve the output quality of generative AI tools (00:04:48).

* Challenges with Scaling Context Management and Infrastructure Mario Konschake noted that Nikita Gorshkov's approach of curating a context knowledge base seems to be a common pattern among AI-engaged product managers (00:06:06). Nikita Gorshkov raised concerns about scaling this, emphasizing the need to define future infrastructure and tools, ideally for one to two years, to avoid multiplying inefficiencies. A critical challenge is the lack of a consolidated source of truth, as people are using various tools, making learning non-transferable and knowledge management a persistent problem (00:07:29).

* Need for Centralized Documentation and Access Nikita Gorshkov highlighted the difficulty in identifying the correct version of documentation across systems like Google Docs, Confluence, and Jira, calling it a "nightmare" that is exacerbated by AI (00:09:07). They noted that institutional knowledge often resides in disparate places‚ÄîSlack, random Google Docs, and code‚Äîand there is no clear indicator of the most current or accurate information (00:11:42). Mario Konschake agreed that the challenge lies in making knowledge accessi



to a little bit

Nikita Gorshkov: Sounds good. And I'll probably as a at some point I'll update the documents that I uh at

 

 

00:27:24

 

Mario Konschake: more.

Nikita Gorshkov: least like I believe in the document I wrote uh before I was building it based on notebook essentially for so that people don't get scared about CLI tools and cursor and stuff like that. Um, I'll probably be updating it to like to that next step of okay, how do you then you do all of the processes that uh you want to automate but through like clock codes for example and then share it at least with my PMs and whoever wants to read it. Um,

Mario Konschake: Yeah,

Nikita Gorshkov: and there's a notebook to ask

Mario Konschake: it would also be good feedback for me to understand like how uh how that will work

Nikita Gorshkov: questions.

Mario Konschake: with your PMS kind of CLI, right? is that is something that they are struggling with or they like first of all are they like curious eager to try it out uh and then is that something that is difficult for them or is that actually something that they can learn if they want to so that's I think it's a very important data point for me at this point as

Nikita Gorshkov: I don't think it's that complic.

Mario Konschake: well

Nikita Gorshkov: It's just you need to get used to it. And yeah.

Mario Konschake: yeah I'm a little bit burned because with starters we've made the assumption that like people can learn git

Nikita Gorshkov: Um,

Mario Konschake: analyst And that was not right. Uh so they they struggle some like some part some uh some of them

Nikita Gorshkov: really

Mario Konschake: struggled with that quite significantly. So that was a bit of a hurdle that we had.

Nikita Gorshkov: interesting.

Mario Konschake: Yeah. But also kit can get really

Nikita Gorshkov: Oh, yeah. It's It's I was What is it?

Mario Konschake: difficult.

Nikita Gorshkov: I had a very simple thing recently. I wanted to have a public repo be created from a folder within my private repo. Nikita / Mario

Meeting records Transcript 





Summary

Mario Konschake and Nikita Gorshkov discussed the definition and rollout of the AI-native Product Development Lifecycle (PDLC), with Mario Konschake expressing concern that product management will become a bottleneck as engineering and UX speed up without proper support for providing fast and better context. Nikita Gorshkov introduced their concept of context-driven product management, detailing a custom automated system that curates a knowledge base of entities and relationships to improve generative AI output, but raised concerns about scaling this approach due to the lack of consolidated infrastructure and the "nightmare" of locating the correct version of institutional knowledge across disparate tools. The participants compared AI models, with Nikita Gorshkov preferring Gemini over Claude for general text and deep research, and they agreed that high-value AI capabilities for product managers lie in data discovery and analysis‚Äîspecifically, using CLI tools to quickly analyze data and identify optimization opportunities.





Details

Notes Length: Standard

* Golden Path for AI-Native PDLC and Product Management Bottlenecks Mario Konschake is working with PEP to define and roll out the golden path for an AI-native Product Development Lifecycle (PDLC) (00:00:00). Mario Konschake explained that while there is a good candidate for software engineers (cloud code spec machine) and initial ideas for UX designers, product management is likely to become the bottleneck if engineering and UX speed up. The challenge lies in effectively supporting product managers in providing better and faster context to feed the development pipeline (00:01:56).

* Context-Driven Product Management and Knowledge Curation Nikita Gorshkov introduced their concept of context-driven product management, which has evolved since its initial version (00:03:19). They believe that product management is highly interconnected, requiring a lift-and-shift transition in working methods rather than peacemeal automation to gain the full benefits of AI. Nikita Gorshkov has developed a custom system using cloud code across two machines to maintain their own knowledge base of entities and relationships, which continuously learns and adds context to improve the output quality of generative AI tools (00:04:48).

* Challenges with Scaling Context Management and Infrastructure Mario Konschake noted that Nikita Gorshkov's approach of curating a context knowledge base seems to be a common pattern among AI-engaged product managers (00:06:06). Nikita Gorshkov raised concerns about scaling this, emphasizing the need to define future infrastructure and tools, ideally for one to two years, to avoid multiplying inefficiencies. A critical challenge is the lack of a consolidated source of truth, as people are using various tools, making learning non-transferable and knowledge management a persistent problem (00:07:29).

* Need for Centralized Documentation and Access Nikita Gorshkov highlighted the difficulty in identifying the correct version of documentation across systems like Google Docs, Confluence, and Jira, calling it a "nightmare" that is exacerbated by AI (00:09:07). They noted that institutional knowledge often resides in disparate places‚ÄîSlack, random Google Docs, and code‚Äîand there is no clear indicator of the most current or accurate information (00:11:42). Mario Konschake agreed that the challenge lies in making knowledge accessi

Dec 18, 2025

Nikita Gorshkov - Appt Booking (Gabriel Greg√≥rio (Senior Product Analyst))

Invited Nikita Gorshkov gabrielgregorio10@gmail.com

Attachments Nikita Gorshkov - Appt Booking (Gabriel Greg√≥rio (Senior Product Analyst)) 

Meeting records Transcript 





Summary

Gabriel Greg√≥rio shared their prior work in data visualization for a wellness company, explaining how they shifted to providing data insights, such as localized user activity metrics around gyms, which significantly enhanced the sales team's negotiation capabilities. Addressing Nikita Gorshkov's query about shortening time to market and running parallel experiments, Gabriel Greg√≥rio suggested incorporating faster research methods like social media surveys or third-party small-group testing alongside traditional A/B testing, citing an example of using two-way messaging for payment reminders at a bank. Gabriel Greg√≥rio also offered region-specific qualitative methods for Brazil, like in-app surveys with discounts, and quantitative methods, such as engaging campaigns or competitions to gather measurable data on potential new users and order frequency, while Nikita Gorshkov clarified that their company is globally hiring for an analytics role and has not yet expanded to Brazil due to requirements around "meat culture," pricing, and infrastructure, though the market is considered interesting.





Details

Notes Length: Standard

* Data Visualization and Insights in the Wellness Sector Gabriel Greg√≥rio discussed their prior work in data visualization for a wellness company, noting that their job became more focused on analyzing and providing insights rather than just sending pre-order information. A significant data point provided was related to user activity around gyms, which included details about subscribers within a certain radius, other types of gyms nearby, and the number of new users resulting from subscription changes, which the company lacked before. This data, visualized in a quick-reference dashboard, enabled the sales team to negotiate with clients more effectively and demonstrate the product's value by offering precise user activity metrics down to the neighborhood level, leading to a new approach for sellers (00:01:49).

* Strategies for Shortening Time to Market Nikita Gorshkov asked Gabriel Greg√≥rio about methods to shorten the time to market and enable multiple experiments in parallel, especially when standard A/B testing takes significant time (00:04:44). Gabriel Greg√≥rio suggested using alternative, faster research methods alongside A/B testing, such as social media surveys or engaging a third-party company for fast research with a small group to quickly validate an idea and then compare the results with the A/B test (00:06:10). Gabriel Greg√≥rio provided an example from their experience working in a bank, where they implemented two-way messaging to measure the impact of payment reminders more quickly than waiting for changes to a website (00:07:27).

* Qualitative and Quantitative Validation Methods Gabriel Greg√≥rio offered qualitative and quantitative methods to shorten the time to results, focusing on what works well in Brazil. Qualitative suggestions included offering discounts or pop-ups within the app for answering surveys or giving ratings, noting that Brazilians are accustomed to responding to in-app interactions and social media engagement (00:09:45). For quantitative validation, especially when traffic is limited, Gabriel Greg√≥rio suggested focusing on measurable goals like potential new users or order frequency and running campaign
